attributes.title: Replication: A Temporal Discontinuity in the Sting of Inferiority at BYU-I Winter 2020
attributes.description:
The level of jealousy and envy felt towards an individual who is experiencing something one desires should be the same regardless of whether the desired experience has already happened or has yet to happen. However, past research has found that timing is an important factor in the amount of jealousy felt when the participants compare themselves to others. Understanding how people react to envy is important in our society where social inequality is continuing to grow. With the growing use of social media, the amount of social comparison among individuals has increased leading to more envy. This study seeks to find potential ways to regulate the amount of envy felt.
This is a replication study and we expect to find more envy and jealousy will be felt before the event has occurred, as the original study did.

attributes.title: Evaluation Schema and Investment to Ventures in Emerging Technology Fields

q1.value: Evaluation Criteria Consensus and Investment to Ventures in Emerging Technology Fields: Contingent Effect of Firm Technological Performance

q3.value: This paper theorizes that consensus in evaluation criteria for a technology will make investors more willing to invest in ventures in that technology field. In this experiment, we examine how the effect of consensus in evaluation criteria varies for firms with different technological performances.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: We have a 2 (evaluation criteria consensus: high versus low) * 3 (firm technological performance: high, unclear, versus low) between-subject design.

q9.value: Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the six conditions by Qualtrics, the survey platform.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from an online platforms, in particular Prolific. Participants will be paid $0.60 for their participation. We recruit participants with managerial experiences.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 900 participants (150 for each condition).

question.value:
We will manipulate the level of evaluation criteria consensus. The two levels are: high versus low. 
We will also manipulate the level of firm technological performance. The three levels are: high, unclear, and low.

1. Investment amount:
 • How much of the$2,000,000 will you invest in this firm? 
2. Willingness to invest (1=strongly disagree to 7=strongly agree)
• I am willing to invest money in this firm. 
• I believe that monetary investment in this firm will yield good returns. 
• This firm presents a great opportunity for investment.

Hypothesis testing (cross-condition comparison): t-test and ANOVA.  
Manipulation check: t-test. 

Manipulation check items: (1=strongly disagree to 7=strongly agree) 
1. Evaluation criteria consensus
• There is consensus about the proper metrics to evaluate image classification algorithms. 
• Academics and industry researchers agree on the metrics to evaluate image classification algorithms. 
• There is a lot of disagreement over the proper metrics to evaluate image classification algorithms. 

2. Firm technological performance
• This firm has demonstrated extraordinary technology capability.	
• This firm builds on reliable technology.	
• This firm utilizes excellent technology.

q22.value: We will exclude the participants (a) who do not pass the simple attention check questions, and (b) who guess the purpose of the study correctly.

q24.value: We are collecting perceptions of others’ investment intention as an exploratory variable. We will test this variable as the mediator in a model where evaluation criteria consensus is the independent variable and investment (intention) is the dependent variable. We will use Hayes’s PROCESS Model 4 with 5,000-time bootstrapping.

attributes.title: Evaluation Schema and Investment to Ventures in Emerging Technology Fields

q1.value: Evaluation Criteria Consensus and Investment to Ventures in Emerging Technology Fields: Testing Multiple Industries/Technology Fields

q3.value: This paper theorizes that consensus in evaluation criteria for a technology will make investors more willing to invest in ventures in that technology field. In this experiment, we test whether the effect of consensus in evaluation criteria for varies across industries and technology fields with different levels of nascence.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Consensus in evaluation criteria for a technology has a positive effect on investment to ventures that uses that technology.
Hypothesis 2: The positive effect of consensus in evaluation criteria on investment is positively moderated by the nascence of the technology such that when the technology is more nascent the effect of evaluation criteria consensus is stronger/more positive, compared to when the technology is less nascent.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: We have a 3-factor 2 (evaluation criteria consensus: high versus low) *2 (industry nascence: high versus low) *2 (technology nascence: high versus low) between-subject design.

q9.value: Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the eight conditions by Qualtrics, the survey platform.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from an online platform, in particular Prolific. Participants will be paid $0.60 for their participation. We recruit participants with managerial experiences.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 960 participants (120 for each condition).

question.value: We will manipulate (a) the level of evaluation criteria consensus, (b) industry nascence level, and (c) technology field nascence level. The two levels for all three variables are: high versus low.

Outcome variables: 
1. Investment amount:
 • How much of the $2,000,000 will you invest in this firm? 
2. Willingness to invest (1=strongly disagree to 7=strongly agree)
• I am willing to invest money in this firm. 
• I believe that monetary investment in this firm will yield good returns. 
• This firm presents a great opportunity for investment.

Hypothesis testing (cross-condition comparison): t-test and ANOVA.  
Manipulation check: t-test. 

Manipulation check items: (1=strongly disagree to 7=strongly agree) 
1. Evaluation criteria consensus
• There is consensus about the proper metrics to evaluate GPS/NLP technology. 
• Academics and industry researchers agree on the metrics to evaluate GPS/NLP technology. 
• There is a lot of disagreement over the proper metrics to evaluate GPS/NLP technology. 

2. Industry nascence level:
How mature is the automotive/drone industry?
• The automotive/drone industry is very mature.							
• The automotive/drone industry is very established.						
• The automotive/drone industry is very new.							
• The automotive/drone industry is very nascent.

3. Technology field nascence level
How mature is the GPS/NLP technology?
• The GPS/NLP technology is very mature.							
• The GPS/NLP technology is very established.							
• The GPS/NLP technology is very new.								
• The GPS/NLP technology is very nascent.

q22.value: We will exclude the participants (a) who do not pass the simple attention check questions and (b) who guess the purpose of the study correctly.

q24.value: We are collecting two exploratory variables: perceived technology capability and others’ investment intention. We will test both variables as the mediator in a model where evaluation criteria consensus is the independent variable and investment (intention) is the dependent variable. We will use Hayes’s PROCESS Model 4 with 5,000-time bootstrapping.

q3.value: Research from Hurst and colleagues (2019; J of business ethics) found that individuals high in primary psychopathy experience less negative emotion when under abusive supervision. We want to investigate whether this is associated with psychopathy or with more of the Dark Triad traits. Further, we want to see if this finding extends to mental health at work, satisfaction, quit intentions, promotion opportunities, and commitment to a job. Finally, we want to see if this extends to exploitative or psychopathic supervision as well.

q4.value: We predict that Machiavellianism and psychopathy (but not narcissism) will show resilience in the face of abusive supervision. With respect to psychopathy, we predict that supervision will have no bearing on intentions to quit, which are typically high among individuals high in psychopathy, anyway. Among individuals high in Machiavellianism, we predict that they will see increased opportunities under dark supervision and will show resilience in the form of satisfaction, mental health, quit intentions, and increased opportunities. These should either be neutral to supervision, or even improve with abusive supervision

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
survey, we will have a large semester survey. However, the only variables analyzed will be the following:

Supervisor rated psychopathy
Abusive supervision
Exploitative supervision
job satisfaction, commitment, and alternatives
quit intentions, 
mental health at work
promotions & opportunities
Dark Triad
demographics (e.g., gender)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: SONA student volunteers. Variables of interest may be isolated and added to with MTUrk participants

q13.value: 250 or until semester ends, or both

q14.value: 250 is fairly standard for correlational studies. We expect typical effect sizes for personality which are correlations between .19-.21

question.value: na

Composites of the following:

Promotions & opportunities
Abusive supervision
Exploitative supervision
psychopathic supervision
Dark Triad (psychopathy, narcissism, psychopathy) using the short dark triad
job satisfaction
job commitment
job alternatives
mental health at work
quit intentions
averaged into composites

hierarchical linear regression, / multiple correlations. We will examine interaction models with supervision*Mach supervision*psychopathy and supervision*Narcissism on the outcomes of interest. Structural equations models, or larger (higher order) composites among the dvs and supervision variables may be warranted if they are too highly correlated

q22.value: survey speed. 6 mins or less will be excluded for the larger survey

q24.value: gender * mach, gender * other dark triad traits. some 3-way interactions (e.g., Mach*gender*supervision)

attributes.title: Emophilia and attraction to the Dark Triad

q1.value: Emophilia and attraction to the Dark Triad

q3.value: We will examine four relationship variables (sociosexual attitudes, anxious attachment, avoidant attachment, and emophilia) and how they predict attraction to a target high vs. low in characteristics of a dark personality individual.

q4.value: We predict that emophilia will outpredict all other variables in wanting a long-term relationship with a dark personality target. Further, there may be an interaction with dark personality and emophilia that predicts increased attraction, or similar attraction to a non-dark personality target. Other individuals are likely drawn to the non dark personality target. Sociosexually unrestricted individuals are likely to be drawn to the dark personality target for short term relationships only.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: we will do a within subjects design, where individuals will simply rate a high vs. low dark personality target for long and short term desired relationships.

q9.value: We will randomize the order of presentation of dark vs. non dark personality target

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: SONA student volunteers and we will add MTurk participants (isolating the variables of interest) if we need more to reach our target sample size.

q13.value: Like most correlational studies, we anticipate an effect size of about .19 - .21 for our correlation / regression. So, 250 should do it.

q14.value: Like most correlational studies, we anticipate an effect size of about .19 - .21 for our correlation / regression. So, 250 should do it.

q15.value: end of the semester. In which case, we may add MTurk participants to supplement. Otherwise, 250 or end of semester.

Anxious / AViodant attachment ECR short form
3 attitude items from Penke SOI-R
Targets of high vs. low dark personality individuals
demographics
averaged into a composite
Multiple regression, Multi-level modeling (accounting for targets nested within participant), and correlations.

q3.value: We are examining how a construct known as "rule governance" may be equivalent to "antisocial behavior" as a facet of psychopathy from the perspective of Hare's four factor model. Rule governance is a measurable trait, thus obviating the need to use behavior to predict personality. Further, we expand upon the deficit model of psychopathy by Newman and colleagues arguing that manipulation, callousness, erratic lifestyle, and antisocial behavior can be conceptualized in their inverse, specifically, a lack of: Honesty/Humility, Empathy, Conscientiousness, and Rule Governance.

q4.value: We predict that rule governance will be a significant and unique contributor in predicting criminal behavior, both major and minor, as well as drug use. We further argue that regressing crime/drugs on honesty/humility, empathy, conscientiousness, and rule governance will reveal similar patterns to those of regressing those criminal outcomes on the four facets of the self-report psychopathy scale (SRP) short form. Finally, Machiavellianism will be unrelated to rule governance, when using the Short Dark Triad. However, short dark triad psychopathy will be strongly and negatively related to rule governance.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will simply survey college students (and turkers if necessary). Note that this is a large semester survey, and we will only include the following variables in our analyses: A four item measure of Rule Governance, a four item measure of Honesty /Humility from the 24 item HEXACO survey, four items of conscientiousness, and four empathy items. We will also include the Short Dark Triad (Jones & Paulhus, 2014), Self-Report Psychopathy scale (SRP) short form, demographics, and 20 or so items from Paulhus's unpublished Criminal Misbehavior Inventory.

q9.value: We will randomize the order of questionnaires, but the criminal behaviors will be second to last, with demographics last.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: student volunteers. if we do not get enough, we will isolate the variables of interest and finish the rest of the needed sample on MTurk

q13.value: We anticipate the effect size to be between (a correlation) to be between .19 and .21, so a sample size of 250 should do it

q14.value: we will run to the end of the semester. If we do not reach our target power, we will isolate the target variables, put them in their own survey, and run on Mturk.

question.value: na

Rule Governance (ad hoc 4 measures)
Honesty / Humility & conscientiousness (HEXACO 24 - 2x 4 item measures)
Empathy (Toronto empathy 4 selected items)
Short Dark Triad
SRP short form (29 items)
CMI crime inventory (Paulhus unpublished measure) selected 20 or so relevant items.
averages will be used and composites analyzed. SRP will be analyzed as a unitary measure as well as at the facet level. Same for HH, Conscientiousness, Rule Gov, and Empathy.

Regressions. We will be mostly analyzing the data in simultaneous regression models. We may also conduct some Structural Equations Models comparing our deficit model with the SRP, especially as related to the outcome variables. We may also examine some Latent variable procedures (i.e., exploratory / confirmatory factor analyses) for our measure of HH, Empathy, Conscientiousness, and Rule Gov.

q22.value: We will use time as an indicator of non-attention. In the big semester survey, less than 6 minutes would be a red flag.

Rule Governance (ad hoc 4 measures)
Honesty / Humility & conscientiousness (HEXACO 24 - 2x 4 item measures)
Empathy (Toronto empathy 4 selected items)
Short Dark Triad
SRP short form (29 items)
CMI crime inventory (Paulhus unpublished measure) selected 20 or so relevant items.
registration_responses.q18.question: averages will be used and composites analyzed. SRP will be analyzed as a unitary measure as well as at the facet level. Same for HH, Conscientiousness, Rule Gov, and Empathy.
registration_responses.q19.question: Regressions. We will be mostly analyzing the data in simultaneous regression models. We may also conduct some Structural Equations Models comparing our deficit model with the SRP, especially as related to the outcome variables. We may also examine some Latent variable procedures (i.e., exploratory / confirmatory factor analyses) for our measure of HH, Empathy, Conscientiousness, and Rule Gov.

q3.value: We are correlating religious overclaiming with abusive behavior towards romantic partners. Specically, we will give participants a "Bible overclaiming" measure asking them to rate how familiar they are with 36 stories from the Bible. However, seven of these stories do not exist. We expect to find that overclaiming religious knowledge is associated with being aggressive towards romantic partners because such individuals (especially men) will take religious license in feeling that it is their "right" to control their partner and that they have power over their partner. However, religiosity will attenuate this effect, such that individuals who are religious will be less abusive.

q4.value: We will use the Signal Detection Theory (SDT) formulas of d' (d prime) and c to calculate accuracy and bias (respectively). We will likely use B'' (B prime, prime) to assess bias (i.e., overclaiming) instead, that will depend on whether or not the foils (i.e., the fictional stories) are normally distributed or not. Typically Bible overclaiming foils are skewed and have high kurtosis. Thus, B'' is a non-parametric test that is more robust to violations of normality in Signal Detection Theory. If there is any doubt, we will report both tests, and will default to "c" if normality violations are mild. We will then correlate  B'' and d' (d prime) with questions related to abuse toward a romantic partner and received by a romantic partner using the Conflict Tactics Scale short form. We predict that (a) Bible Overclaiming will predict abuse of romantic partners, (b) this effect will be moderated by gender, such that men who overclaim will be the most abusive, and men who do not will be least abusive. Finally, religiosity should moderate overclaiming such that those who are highly religious should be gentle. Specifically, B'' should have a negative correlation (which indicates a positive relationship in SDT formulas) with abuse.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: survey. Note that this is a large semester survey. Thus, there are a lot of measures in here that are not related to this particular study, and will not be analyzed. To be clear, our study will involve: Religiosity, BOCQ (thats "BIBLE OVERCLAIMINIG QUESTIONNAIRE") gender (and other demographics), and the conflict tactics scale.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: No exclusion. Student SONA volunteers and MTurk (maybe, if there aren't enough students by the end of the term).

q13.value: In a recent publication (Jones et al., SPPS in press), we found that 157 was enough to detect an effect. However, we have already run 1 study on this effect and the correlation was .182, and this amounts to a needed 234 for 80% power. Thus, we will try to collect around 250 students. Although note, the semester is halfway through now, so if we do not achieve 250, we may turn to isolating only the variables of interest for this study and turn to MTurk.

However, we have already run 1 study on this effect and the correlation was .182, and this amounts to a needed 234 for 80% power. Thus, we will try to collect around 250 students. Although note, the semester is halfway through now, so if we do not achieve 250, we may turn to isolating only the variables of interest for this study and turn to MTurk.

q22.value: time of survey. We will have several readers go through it. I anticipate less than 6 minutes, they didn't take it seriously.

q24.value: moderations with age, gender, socioeconomic status.
